38940501.review:
This game hits me right in the nostalgic chuddies. It is a homage to all the great arcade side-scrolling beat 'em ups of yore, and a greta game in its own right.
Combat is simple but with depth, fully utilising the limited control scheme for fluid combos and satisfying punchy sounds.
Personally I turned off the CRT emulation effect, but it is a fun addition aesthetically. The charcaters themselves have that classic 16bit feel, complemented by a selection of unlockable costumes. Remember that, when costumes were unlockables and not microtransactions? Ah youth...
I love that you can also unlock enemy characters then brawl with them in Battle mode.

The only major letdown is the lack of an online multiplayer (unless you run Win 8+ and use something like parsegaming).
Other than that, you should totally buy this.

38863164.review:
Six hours in I'm already addicted. At first I as disappointed that there weren't that many attack options, but then I realized it's the right handful amount for all the combo possibilities you can connect. The graphics are nice 16-bit arcade style I grew up, the soundtrack rocks, and the gameplay is fluid once you understand what the characters can do.

Fight'N Rage really is an easy game to pick up as the controls are easy to learn, but learning how to connect them and discovering enemy strategies is where the challenge lies. I feel like the people who complain about this game's difficulty are far too used to AAA titles where flash takes presecedence over substance. Not that I don't like AAA games and their graphics. Of course there's amazing action set pieces found in stuff like Uncharted or the new Tomb Raider games and those are thrilling to play--but the CHALLENGE from games of yesteryear has been lacking in the AAA department and can mostly be found by indie developers.

Enter in FNR and you've got yourself a challenging and replayable game where there is no hand holding auto save, and each time you play you need to commit to the 1-2+ hours it takes to get through the varying paths you can take in the game. The time my vary based on how many continues you require, but if you're smart, you can easily learn how to use the combo system to your advantage and survive better when you figure out how enemies behave.

38843246.review: best beat em up since GOD HAND

38803738.review:
You can tell someone loved Final Fight and Streets of Rage a little too much! As the name sounds, this is a pure Arcade-style Beat 'em up with so many ideas taken from the two game and a few more. It is easy to get into for any player as it is a bit of a button-mashing combo brawler, but it can be difficult to master if you rely on aggressive button usage over actual timing, reflexes, and a bit of strategy as well as learning enemy patters and weaknesses.
Everything in this game will remind you of one of the two games it is based on. The music, the arcade machines, the weapons and food, the regular enemies, even some of the bosses. Oh, and there are multiple endings, multiple characters, and you can play 3-player co-op straight from the start. There is also a lot to unlock, so you aren't just playing repeatedly for endings or measly achievements. You are playing to gain access to more ways to play the game.
BTW, I just played for 2-hours straight on my first try because I had to beat this game. I can't remember the last time I did that, but it was that good.

38779040.review:
I recommend this game to everyone out there looking for a good brawler. It is the easy to learn, but hard to master type of game wher you can have some quick fun, but you can also go hardcore and die a lot until you got the hang of all the things you can do in this deep fighting system.
Honestly it feels almost as deep as a lot of those complex 1v1 beat'em ups. The good thing is, Fight'N Rage provides you with a training mode to try and learn all the possibilities.
On top of that the game features lots of unlocks and alternate routes with many different endings to see.
The fights themselves have the right kind of "punchy" feel to it with so much satisfaction to kick, throw and punch your way through the enemies.

I honestly thought this looked pretty "meh" from the trailer, but ate my words tenfold after playing it.

Pretty much, This takes the best of Capcom arcade brawlers (Final Fight, The Punisher and Alien VS Predator spring to mind) and the best of Streets of Rage Remake, and then adds a little Street Fighter 3 Parrying. Theres also Juggle combos, and cancels too, which are handled really well.

Easily the best beat em up on Steam, and all the gameplay balance patches have been and gone, so Its actually what I would call a finished product. The soundtrack is bloody fantasic to boot, and the animations are smooth. I also have not encountered a single major glitch since playing, and I've clocked well over 100 hours, which is utterly remarkable in this day and age. (Looking at you, River City Ransom Underground)

My only real complaint, personally, is a sad lack of online play (There is work-arounds, though), but it WAS made by one man, after all. I would like to hope this will be something that will be addressed in the hopeful sequel.

Some people might not be keen on the difficulty, but at no point is it unfair (unless you play Unfair Mode haha) and be mastered with a good bit of practice. If you are into this genre, you will probably be very pleased with this, so at least check it out.

Edit: There's also a small mod community, so If you like to make custom sprites/animations/palettes, there alot of fun to be had here, if you have the patience to learn how.

38227682.review:
Abso-fuckin'-lutely worth your time. This is love letter to beat-em-ups of the 90s, and if you grew up with Final Fight, Streets of Rage and the like, this plays like a perfected, smoothed, updated version of those games.

Not only is the guy behind this (literally built by one dude, and I've never seen a game made by one man be so fluid, complete, and not-jank) is obviously a fan of the Street Figher Alpha series as well (as am I, which definitely helps my opinion, but I don't think it's necessary for someone to love this game), from the rotation decals on a spinning enemy being identical to the ones after an Alpha Counter in those games to charaters like Tsong Doo, the rooster who uses Muay Thai and stands on one foot with a mong-kon on, a perfect reference to Adon. Hell, there's a female ninja named Gal who has Guy's exact walk cycle (and F. Norris, the male ninja character, has his exact bread-and-butter combo). There's SF III as well, in the Doberman enemy who boxes you, including Dudley's exact Corkscrew Blow animation. Or the enormous water buffalo named T. Bison who does turnpunches. Or the cat enemy who is dressed exactly like M. Bison (Dictator) and attacks with slide kicks and scissorkicks. Homeboy is a Street Fighter fan, for sure.

There's three characters, Gal (the quick one), F. Norris (the all-arounder), and Ricardo (a bull with a penchant for wrestling moves, from powerbombs to lariats). The story is some kind of catastrophe went down and annihilated human technology while also mutating animals into sapient, humanoid forms. Suffice it to say, they are displeased with their treatment by people, and you are out to stomp 'em back out. Don't feel bad; they've enslaved and eaten loads of people. Stomp 'em back down to their places on the food chain!

Combat feels wonderful. Animations are smooth and buttery. Basic X-X-X-X combos give way to dash attacks, anti-airs and special moves. Everybody has a completely unique moveset and when you find out you can backfist-combo a dude into a roundhouse, then dash forward and slidekick him before he hits the ground to juggle him into a tatsu, or execute Gal's full basic  combo into a guy, cancel into her special move to launch the poor bastard straight up, bread-and-butter him again, THEN flipkick him until he EXPLODES INTO BONES, well, suffice it to say it is IMMENSELY gratifying. Dudes swarm you, but your verbset, while not particularly expansive, combos and interconnects so well, you can dish out pain commensurate with the enemy floods.

Unlockables are through the ROOF. Extra game modes like difficulties or speed settings, some eleven costumes for each character (I don't even have them all for my favorite character yet), and a battle mode where you can play as each of the enemy types, meaning you've got them to unlock, too. There's an entire grid of endings, with some 30 or so possible permutations. You can even unlock a CPU assist mode where you can play with an AI partner (or two!) to get the endings that require multiple characters, even if you don't have buddies who play beat-em-ups available.

I had a feeling I was going to like this game as soon as it pretended to the RAM check cycle that old arcade cabinets did back in the day. I was further convinced of the love and care of the dev when I saw that there are friggin' video modes to mimic the CRTs of days of old, even simulated GLARE, for Christ's sake. The music is great, the gameplay is so smooth you're liable to slide out of your chair, and the references are charming as all get-out. I cannot say enough good about it, and I legitimately believe it is impossible to go wrong for the price. Pick it up, for sure.

と言っていい内容。
挟み撃ちを仕掛けてくる雑魚軍団、エレベーターや乗り物での闘い、殴っていて気持ちのいい重量感のある打撃音とヒットストップ。目新しさは無いけれども往年のベルトスクロールらしさが詰まっています。

経験値や、キャラクターの強化であるとか、ゲーム内の難易度に影響を及ぼすようなものはありません。あくまでACライク。キャラクターの強さに関わるのはプレイヤーの腕前のみ！

ステージの殆どが夜や薄暗い屋内で、明るいステージが少ない。

37563396.review:
Beat-em-ups like this just don’t come around that often anymore.

All too many nowadays try to basically be bad 2D fighters in disguise, focus so much on spectacle that the entire screen is nothing but a chaotic mess where you’re sure your character is in there SOMEWHERE, or just plain work too hard at reinventing the wheel while forgetting there’s a reason your tires don’t look like the squiggly blocks from Tetris.

But HERE… imagine a beat-em-up where the creator clearly loved the genre and plucked the best bits from the genre.

-You’ve got branching paths through the story that can bring you as long or as short an experience as you like, depending on the route you feel like taking.

-Enemies actually fight differently from one another, and there’s no situation you can’t control as long as you know what to watch for and how to play your foes off each other.

-Hell, YOUR CHARACTERS play very differently from one another, and while your move list for any given one is far more extensive than you might anticipate (and you can even buy a non-DLC training mode that lets you give them a test run), you CANNOT play either of the three heroes like you would the others (unless you like game over screens, of course).

-The combat engine is more robust than your average beat-em-up, but not so much so that it’s completely overwhelming and inexplicably requires you to memorize a giant list of complicated commands in order to make any sort of forward progress.

-You’ve got a very wide range of difficulty settings that do everything from alter the enemies’ health and aggressiveness, to making little alterations to the game’s rules – but it’s done in a way that subtly encourages you to step things up a notch once you think you’ve mastered your current difficulty, as opposed to just locking half the game’s playable content behind your difficulty setting.

-There’s an in-game shop that lets you buy a variety of game features, including new modes, new difficulty settings, new looks for your characters, and a number of other amusing little odds and ends.

-There’s a couple of cute little jokes about the genre and a few bits where the inspirations were a bit more obvious than most.

-You've got an EXCELLENT soundtrack that always feels like it matches the action on the screen.

-And hell, it’s just a damn fine rampage against the mutant hordes that could do with a bit of a bodyslam. ;3


Put it all together with an enthusiastic developer who clearly wants you to enjoy the game as much as he VERY obviously enjoyed making it, and you’ve got one of the finest beat-em-ups of this era - hell, this would’ve easily been among the highest tiers of the genre even in the best days of beat-em-ups!

The price may be a little on the steep side, but think of it this way - you’re buying one of the best games the genre has to offer, for a third of what you’d pay for a console port back in the 90s. It’s worth it. =3

36961751.review:
Tenemos ante nosotros, mis estimados gamers y classic gamers, un tremendo beat’em up que claramente hace alusión a los mejores del género durante la “época dorada” allá por principios y mediados de los ’90. Básicamente, Fight N Rage tiene todo lo que un buen título de esta estirpe debe posser: historia simple, acción frenética, dificultad notable y desde ya, el eterno factor de la rejugabilidad, tanto en solitario como entre amigos.

En un mundo en guerra, los mutantes y los humanos no han logrado llegar a un buen acuerdo, por lo que los primeros mencionados establecen un caos general, asesinando y devastando a mansalva. Un grupo de héroes, unidos por la misma causa – y en algunos casos, con algún problema personal con el enemigo -, deciden realizar justicia por mano propia.

Inicialmente, contamos con tres personajes distintos para iniciar la aventura: Gal, F. Norris y Ricardo, cada uno con las típicas características y balances en cuanto a movilidad o potencia de ataque. A disposición nuestra se encuentra también un modo de entrenamiento, realmente útil para aprender nuevas técnicas, movimientos o combos. Conforme avancemos, notaremos una enorme influencia – positiva, desde ya – de títulos como Streets of Rage, Final Fight, Cadillacs & Dinosaurs y otras sagas de toda la vida. A priori, también tendremos el desafío de ver cuán oxidados estamos ante un video game cuya dificultad va en notable crecimiento.

La posibilidad de elegir varios caminos hasta llegar al enemigo final, es otra peculiaridad, favoreciendo también el factor “rejugabilidad” mencionado al inicio. La enorme variedad de opciones, personajes, modos de juego y extras, son otro motivo más por el cuál entender que la primera vez que podamos finalizarlo, en realidad es sólo el inicio. Y ni hablar si sos de los que no pueden dejar de completar todos los logros en Steam, claro.

El despliegue gráfico es realmente bueno, con una estética de 16 Bits y detalles interesantes por todas partes. En cuanto a la personalización, encontré también muy interesante la cantidad de variantes que ofrece para visualizarlo; es decir, que podremos jugarlo con scanlines, en modo “limpio”, como si fuera una TV vieja, etc. Detalles no menores y que valen la pena mencionar. En cuanto a la parte del sonido y la música, son magníficos, evocando también aquellas melodías que acompañaban durante la aventura y que en realidad uno termina apreciando la segunda o tercera vez que le dedica tiempo.

Sin miedo a equivocarme, Fight N Rage es sin duda alguna un “nuevo clásico” que además, tiene el orgullo de haberse desarrollado en Sudamérica, específicamente en Uruguay. Un excelente laburo que por un precio accesible, nos puede proporcionar horas de diversión “cómo las de antes”. Eso sí, no te pongas nervioso si perdés en el cuarto nivel!

36881399.review:
If you are a fan of beat em' ups, brawlers, or fighting games in general; do yourself a favor and pick this little gem up. Its like where to start? First off the graphics and art are outstanding, lots of the character/enemy sprites for the most part have fluid animations, especially the females...they have bits that jiggle so much that it puts the jiggle physics of DOA Volleyball and Senran Kagura series to shame; some might find it off putting or a nit pick, but me, I enjoy this man's work, attention and detail to those parts; with that aside the other enemies you ecounter in game have unique and interesting designs each with different fighting styles that are heavily influenced by Street Fighter (like come on, there is an enemy that dresses and fights like M.Bison).

Next is the controls and combat, Fight'N Rage has this down to a tee; it's a simple three button layout you got your attack, jump, and a button for you special attack. It's one of these easy to pick up hard to master sort of combat; you got foward attacks, down attacks, jump attacks, running attacks, grabs/throws, parries, cancels, combos, big combos the list goes on. The dev was clearly influence by the Street Fighter combat mechanics and it works so well in a beat em' up so big props to them.

I got not much to say about the music, but I know good music when I hear it and this game totally has it. The main menu music hypes you up for beating up these fucking furries; and track after track keeps the blood pumping. So yeah, compliments to the composer very well done. Might as well also mention the difficulty, this game is pretty rock hard and I will admit with no shame that I havent beaten it yet, it gets to Cuphead levels of hard, maybe a bit harder than that; so just a fair warning. There is an "easy mode" but you need to unlock it first with points. 

As for everything else I havent mentioned, like the story; its just there to be there, nothing too deep or a meaning behind it; You as the humans (or the only furry that fights along with the humans) have to fight through stages of "mutants" (they are anthros) to get to the boss. Simple and straightfoward yeah, but truth be told, there are branching paths in certain stages that will change the game's ending, so there is high replayability to have here. Along with story mode you got a shop where you can buy a plethora of things from main character skins, game modes, and new characters for your battle mode. And dont worry, no microtransactions on this. Its just a matter of scoring high on story mode to obtain coins and thats how you buy things, so thats another plus there, no lootboxes or microtransaction bullshit.

[b] TL;DR, GOOD BEAT UP FURRIES SIMULATOR [/b]

36481739.review:
Fight'n Rage is a love letter to beat 'em ups of the past, a genre not really seen anymore. This is inspired by games such as Streets of Rage and Final Fight, games I really enjoyed when I was younger!

During my first playthrough I didn't really catch much of the story: Think it's that mutants are running amok and on a genocidal rampage against the humans. Enter you, the protagonist, to beat up hundreds of them. You can unlock a lot of extra characters but you start with 3:

-Gal, a lady who's all about speed, combos, and jiggling---I mean, juggling. And jiggling.
-F. Morris, a strategic fighter with numerous strategies.
-Ricardo, a minotaur with massive strength to crush foes.

I played through as Gal the first time, and the fighting felt really good. Pulling off crazy combos while surrounded by enemies feels amazing, and the enemy variety is large enough to the point it never really feels boring. Combine that with an awesome rocking soundtrack and you got all you need for a fantastic beat 'em up. Not to mention very well animated sprites for both the characters and the enemies: Game looks really good.

The way it differs from many others is how it has multiple routes and endings. You can take different paths to go to different stages, and fight different foes. This gives the game a ton of replayability, and I'm looking forward to my next run!

I played on Normal, and for the most part the game was reasonable in terms of difficulty! There's some REALLY rough stretches in the end stages but with a little strategy you can make things a lot easier for yourself. There's only one stage which started to test my patience, and that was a raft stage where you fight a lot of enemies on a small raft. You can knock them into water, but the same can happen to you and you take a chunk of damage when that happens. It gets worse when you start fighting enemies that cannot fall into the water, and there are zero health drops during this entire section.

This raft stage ended with a really bad boss, and that leads to one of my bigger complaints: The boss design is kinda inconsistent. This particular boss could not be harmed by anything but jump kicks and special attacks as they were often floating over the water. Most of the fight had me just doing jump kicks as he dove for me, and...It was really bad.

Still, there's a number of enjoyable fights, it's just some weak bosses thrown in there.

Overall, if you loved the beat 'em ups of yesteryear, you'll love this game. The game took me 2 hours to beat the first run, and now that I have a run under my belt I can probably annihilate that time. You also have a ton of unlockables, a ton of modes, a lot of customization...You get a whole lot for $20!

I give this a hearty recommendation.

If I had to say, I'd probably say that I'm a Beat Em' Up novice. I viciously and without remorse cheated to get max stats in Scott Pilgrim, I played Red knight in Castle Crashers and grinded my way to becoming an invincible wall of lightning and in Guardian Heroes I couldn't beat the game without getting that extreme buff from the magic sword. About the only "real" beat em ups I ever won were ones that got re-released with infinite continues.

So why then, did I buy this? Well to be blatantly honest, I had heard about it on a minor gamming site thought to myself "yeah that looks cool" and bought it once I had the available cash. My total regrets since then have been negligable. Sure, my first run basically ended in failure, but this time, this time I truly fought the game. I didn't just go "well time to grind up exp or find an easier route". Nope. I just went and said "fine, I'll buy easy mode". I then proceeded to try again(I won that time), get some practice in the training room, and read a helpful guide. After that, I truly started enjoying the game by blasting hundred of poor rats into thin gruel as Ricardo and my first "true" run ended up being my first single credit clear.

Welp, that's my little "backstory talk". Let's talk actual game design stuffs. The game is just one big chunk of eye and ear candy. Amazing sprites on amazing backgrounds all while listening to a godly soundtrack. It's just pure nerve pleasing goodness. for gameplay, well, it's bog standard beat em up. You can move around in a "3D" envirnment, you have your basic combo button, jump button, and special button(or Lariat button for Ricardo) so you shouldn't have any problems figuring things out. The game is also quite responsive and for everything that goes on(especially in three player co-op) I'm quite happy that my little laptop has only ever had a problem with this game when it's hooked up to my tv. Of course, despite my aformentioned "domination" of the game, it isn't roll over levels of easy. There are some enemies(looking at YOU Doberman) that are pretty dang tough. But what's really nice is how addicting and replayable it is. There's a ton of endings to get and metric tons of unlockables(though, easy mode is for some reason one of them). Perhaps the most amusing of which is the ability to play as all those outright useless mooks you slaughter by the dozen. There's just something about watching the two weakest enemies in the game fight each other that is so hilarious.

Good:
Very pretty
Rocking Sound track
Fun characters to learn and master
Unlockables for days
Good stress reliever with proper unlocks

You can make aformentioned rat and cat EXPLODE into a pile of bones
AI helpers for when you don't have any friends

Neutral:
Have to unlock modes that lower the dificulty
There's no point in making apple peeler rat and thunder cat fight
AI helpers won't eat chicken with you

Bad:
No online(okay there sort of is, and I don't care about online anyway but might as well point it out since "everything must be online")
You will(most likely) hurl death threats at a knife weilding armadillo thing and subsequently get everyone in the room to look at you funny
AI helpers have a tendancy to die because they won't eat their chicken

El juego cuenta con una jugabilidad buenisima, la cual es sencilla pero al mismo tiempo profunda, para que tanto los nuevos como los veteranos en el juego, puedan disfrutar de la misma.

Su apartado grafico es impecable, esta muy bien hecho cada escenario, cada sprite, cada efecto. Es precioso de ver.

Que decir de su apartado sonoro, los efectos suenan de miedo, y las musicas se adaptan perfectamente a cada escenario. Gracias a los temazos de Gonzalo Varela.

Es muy rejugable, ya que tiene muchisimos finales y rutas. Aparte que todos los elementos bloqueados, los podras desbloquear tan solo jugando. Como los buenos juegos!

Jugar con mas de un jugador es multiplicar la diversion, haciendo combos brutales con tu compañero.

Se ve que el juego esta hecho con mucho cariño y esmero.

Hay varios modos de juego aparte del arcade, podras desbloquearlo mediante las monedas que ganaras jugando en el modo arcade.
--------------------------

Como contra podriamos decir...

El modo dificil es pasable... Pero el modo de dificultad "Muy Dificil" puede resultar un autentico infierno, sobre todo para el personaje de Gal, incluso siendo experto jugando con ella. Ya que con los otros no tendras muchos problemas.
Tampoco hay checkpoints, si continuas, volveras al inicio del nivel. Esto en la ultima fase es realmente IMPOSIBLE, ya que debes de pasar TOOODO el nivel con tan solo tres vidas, y probablemente no ganes ninguna vida extra.

El parry a veces no funciona correctamente, incluso haciendo bien el cambio de sentido. Tampoco otorga tiempo de inmunidad, lo que significa que si has bloqueado un golpe de un combo enemigo, recibiras el siguiente golpe, a no ser que lances la habilidad especial de imediato.

Algunas zonas pueden resultar caoticas debido a la cantidad de enemigos que salen en pantalla. No puedes ni ver a tu personaje entre tanto bicho (Dificil o superior).

Veo a Gal un tanto nerf en comparacion con los demas personajes. Lo unico que veo que destaca es en su habilidad para escapar de los enemigos, pero no es la gran cosa. Su daño es bajo pese a que sus combos son largos, su rango es MUY corto, su velocidad es similar a la de Norris y es la mas debil de los tres.

No hay ningun item que otorgue una vida extra, solo podras conseguir vidas mediante puntos.

No tiene Coop online, aun que puedes jugar con un amigo online mediante programas como Parsec.
--------------------------

Este analisis esta sujeto a cambios debido a las actualizaciones del desarrollador.

Basic down up attacks, juggling, and other combos are just impossible for me to perform in this game reliably, even when i regularly do all the above in other games.  

If I could play on easy mode, I would probably have enjoyed the game more, but that requires in game currency to unlock (Like Seriously? Hard mode is free, but you need to pay for easy mode?). 36101585.review:
Do you like punching furries in the face?  I know I do, and not only is it cathartic, it's fun too.  With a complex combat system that'd make most modern beat'em ups blush Fight'n Rage is definitely worth the price tag.

The combat in F'N Rage is crunchy, brutal, flashy, fun, and filled with some hidden depth that really pays off if you're willing to take some time to master it.  Each of the three protagonists has their own, unique playstyle, and if you find one isn't working for you odds are one of the others will be more your speed.  Unlike a lot of it's contemporaries, F'N Rage doesn't bullshit around with shoehorned in RPG elements or obnoxious progression systems either.  You don't fill an XP meter to unlock that special or pour a few more points into your HP to make it past that boss, you just get better at the game.  

Yes, Fight'N Rage is difficult, almost ball-bustingly so.  Though it's rarely unfair, if you're willing to invest the time and effort into learning the stages and the way certain enemies work, you'll make it through.  If you're not, then you're probably about halfway through leaving a complaint in the community hub about how the difficulty needs to be nerfed.  If you're new, or unsure of your ability, however, have no fear, there IS an easy mode and a training dojo that will help you get to grips with some of the carachters' more complex moves.  However, it is worth noting that these modes are locked behind a virtual paywall within the game, I'm not sure what the logic was behind locking them away at the start, when hard mode is available right off the bat, but you will have to grind through a stage or two on normal difficulty before you can dip your toes into an easier puddle.  

Visually, the game puts most indie titles to shame.  None of that 1 block pixel-art bullshit here, every enemy, protagonist, and big-bouncing titty is rendered in loving detail.  And depending on how old-school you want to go, you can make the game look like it's playing in a shitty arcade cabinet CRT, just like when your momma used to pawn you off in the local mall's arcade in the hopes some strange man would abduct and kill you so she wouldn't have to pay for your school supplies and macaroni no more.  Sadly, the screaming asian kid over at the DDR pad and the cigarette smoke are not graphical features included within this game, which is a shame, because then it'd be TRULY nostalgic.  

The music is great too, though I found it fading into the background of fights more often than not, it does an excellent job of complimenting the chaos on screen and there are some truly atmospheric tracks here and there that can set a more somber/sinister tone as the moment allows.

If you're one of those pansies who likes 'story' in their games, there really isn't much here.  Mutants are dicks and you're gonna punch them in the face, though it's worth noting that there are a plethora of routes and endings to unlock, complete with exclusive stages and cutscenes that shed a little more light on the plot.  As of this review I've only managed to snag a couple, but the variance is a nice touch and makes repeat playthroughs just a smidgen more interesting than they might be otherwise.  

So far, can't recommend it enough if your a fan of the genre or oldschool games in general.  If you're not experienced with this kind of game, however, and don't want to put the effort in to overcome the challenge it offers, then you might want to look elsewhere.

36008630.review:
Fight'N Rage is possibly one of the best beat-em-up to be conceived into the over saturated gaming generation. If you're looking for an indie title to take you back to the golden age of beat-em-ups from the 80's and 90's, Fight'N Rage is that title. It borrows some of the best elements of titles of old like Streets of Rage, Double Dragon, Battletoads, etc. while adding its own original modern take on the now niche genre with its unique artstyle and its simple to pick up, but hard to master gameplay mechanics.  


Pros:
- The 3 main characters have their own individual movesets
- Good sizable replay value with plenty of extra modes and unlockables to earn
- Gameplay is easy to pick up, but has a steep learning curve for pulling off the most advance techniques
- The 7 stages have various paths to take that can lead to one of several different endings

Cons:
- The Artstyle ( particularly Gal and the female enemies and NPCs) might turn off some
- No online co-op
- A single playthrough ( which can take over an hour) might have some gamers burn out from repetition

FightN' Rage is a side scrolling beat em up tracing its ancestory to Streets of Rage and River City Ransom.

What I loved:
+The fighting is responsive and kinetic. It's very satisfying to beat the crap out of hordes of enemies. Particularly when you air juggle their corpse long enough to make it explode.
+The character designs are interested and fun
+There's branching story based on in game choices. Which characters you are playing as has slight changes to the ending as well. There's a lot of replayability here.

What I didn't Like:
- You can unlock enemies to use in battle but only for the arena not the story mode. Their move sets aren't really fleshed out enough to be usable that way anyway. Would love to see this added in the sequel.
- The story ends with a painfully obvious set up for a sequel.

In conclusion, if you like side scrolling beat em ups you'll love this game. Get it now. If you're not really a fan of them you'll probably enjoy this as well but pick it up on sale.

35823214.review:
I'm giving this game a 9.5/10 RECOMMENDED because its a side scrolling beat'em up done so well and so good... so anywho... my review... somewhat spoiler free. [Overview positive and negative list at the bottom if you don't wanna read the review]

90s kids... 16-bit generation video gamers of the Sega and Nintendo variety... have been missing out on a lot of button mashing action? Missing the blood pumping fist of fury, cracking suckers skull in with a metal pipe of the old days...? People... Fight'N Rage... IS YOUR CALLING!

Fight'N Rage is an action side scrolling beat'em up brawler that seems like a lost gem in the archives of Sega and Nintendo alike. Back before the days of online gaming... you had to invite a friend over [Couch co-op] to help you trash the likes of punks staking the mean streets in this game and I like it like that. (Lets get this out of the way first THERE IS NO ONLINE CO-OP! BUT THIS ISN'T A BAD THING!) This game take me back to those good'ol days of 16-bit gaming at its finest. It wasn't about me vs some player across the world in a STREET FIGHTER match... nope this was me against the evil computer characters and you felt more like a BAD DUDE ridding the STREET OF RAGE full evil on your own and it felt good. A single player optional co-op experience is hard to pull off nowadays, and with new twists and turns added for higher replay value is something you don't see much of in this genre of video gaming.

No spoilers about the story but lets talk about the presentation: lets just say it has a rave night club style in the menus, and comic book like flare in-game similar to a Sega Genesis game we played called Comic Zone. You can even make the screen look like an old fasion Cathode Ray Tube TV for old school effects! [That's the old heavy CRT TVs before the flat panel ones were out.] Yes I went on about the 16-bits... because the game has the old school style sprites in a 32-bit style fashion, you could say it has a PS1 sprite style upgrade. 

Characters... quite a bit of them... and each with their own story, personality, attacks, moves and patterns, each new stage has new challenging enemies and bosses that you have to learn patterns in and out. The grunge like designs are things that feel like out of the 90s with post-apocalyptic movie like style... oh yea and there are anthropomorphic or furry characters in the game. Nice shout out to the furry community! 

And the music... man if this kicking soundtrack doesn't get your emotions up and blood pumping to 'Fight'N Rage' I don't know what will. 

Gameplay is easy to pick up and play but hard to master with only 3 action buttons [Attack, Jump and Special] and each character plays differently Like Streets of Rage 1, 2 and 3, and Final Fight 1, 2 and 3 and is a welcome change from recent beat'em ups. But what makes only 3 buttons so special? Because all the characters have multiple attacks, moves and special attacks...[EVEN HIDDEN MOVES]... Oh and you can juggle enemies for crazy combos. Its like Alien vs Predator arcade's gameplay thrown into the mix to make this game something very special. And you can Overkill [Crushed as the game calls it] enemies for more points... so GO CRAZY ON COMBOS!

Now I'm just gonna list a few game series [and some influences] that this game pays great tribute too:
Streets of Rage - [characters, weapons, 3's Special attack meter and dash attacks, Bikers!]
Comic Zone - [art style, and story progression format]
Bad Dudes - [Evil Ninjas]
Final Fight - [characters, weapons, 3's CPU player characters and Super Meter]
Alien vs Predator arcade - [Ram Rom check screen, air juggle system and timer countdown system]  
Double Dragon - [weapons, environmental hazards]
Street Fighter - [Characters and move sets]
And I'm sure there are a lot more but... not gonna say everything...

And what is gonna keep you; the player, coming back for more of the difficulty of repetitiveness? Why the many unlocks of course! As you play through the game... points are converted to coins [rather if you clear the game or lose all your lives in a single run] that you can buy characters [for other modes, not story mode], other modes, options and costumes! 

But you are probably saying... "That's it!?" No! Want a tougher challenge? Use those coins to unlock harder diffculties give yourself an even harder challenge in story mode and unlock even more things. 

"Harder challenge are you crazy!? What else does the game have?" Well the big kicker to replay value in this game... In story mode... there are multiple paths, surprises at every corner and multiple endings... FOR EACH CHARACTER!! And group of characters... because this is a 1, 2 or 3 player game... [buy the special CPU-Player option if you are a lonely gamer and let the CPU team up with you as a character... like myself who only plays with online friends. Sad face...] 

Like I said, high replay values like unlockables for these kind of games are rather rare and without them make it harder for newcomers in this old genre of video games due to the repetitiveness of action in them to enjoy mulitple times, but here Fight'N Rage has made higher replay value fun and rewarding and has found a place in my gaming list that I will gladly play over and over again and with all of this extra content and you; the player, will probably put this on your list of games you'll probably play until the end of time! You'll probably still be figuring out sweet combo attacks by then. And with periodic updates from the designer, this game totally will be improved for the better overtime.

So here are overview positives & negatives [gotta be fair] for Fight'N Rage if you don't wanna read my lengthy review:

+ Fast pace button mashing action
+ Tricky enemy patterns to make you think a little [NOT A LOT] and environments
+ A great juggling + combo system
+ Items are everywhere even defeated enemies drop them
+ Each character feels, plays and acts differently with many moves and attacks with a simple button set
+ Furry character [+ sexy designs]
+ The Rock hard music sets the tone of the game
+  High replay values with MULTIPLE PATHS AND ENDINGS FOR EACH CHARACTER! And makes it feel rewarding with also UNLOCKABLES AND OPTIONS! Using points to convert into in-game currency to buy these hidden goodies
+ A good thought out story that involves each of the main characters you play as
+ Classic art design of the 90s video games.

- No online multiplayer... aww...
- newcomers may feel a bit cheated and overwhelmed with all this craziness and difficulty of action happening at once for the first few times playing.
- Need to unlock easy mode first before you can use this mode.
- And a quick save option is needed for those who can't sit for a whole hour or more to 1 credit clear the game.
- Training mode needs to be re-adjusted with attack combos or add two enemies and remove or increase the timer for black belt promotion.
- No 1up items only can get extra lives through high scoring.

And final few pointers
You will need to be patient sometimes and take on a few enemies a time, you will fail quite a number of times [Especially if you charge right in and agro 7, 8 and 9 enemies on screen at once] and on continuing [losing all your lives] the game takes you back sometimes to the beginning of the stage as punishment.

You will need to learn your character's move sets, enemy move and attack patterns, save food items for when low on health, build up points for extra lives [50,000 points=1up is the only way to get extra lives] or face the consequences!

So fingers, fists and feet do the talking with Fight'n Rage!

One of the best side scrolling beat-em-ups I have played in a long time.

Very reminiscent of 90s games such as Streets of Rage and Final Fight,
so it's great if you love those sort of games.

Unlike those games of the past though, this genuinely feels like the next step gameplay wise.
The potential for combos and setups is incredible, sometimes it feels like you are playing a fighting game like Street Fighter within a beat-em-up.

This game is challenging so be warned if you are a casual player like me,
and it will take practice to get to grips with combos, parrying attacks, learning patterns - 
but it's so worth it!

It's alot of fun, especially multiplayer, for which up to 3 can play.
Music is very memorable too, and really spurs you on.

There are secrets to unlock too, including new costumes, game modes/quality of life options.

Persevere and enjoy!

35722365.review:
This game is a very solid old school themed beat 'em up. This also means that it inherits the flaws that have been in this genre since the 90s. Enemies will stay off screen if they feel like it and also combo you to death when they sorround you. Your characters are balanced differently, but not for the best in most cases. The Bosses will get very cheap to the point of pure frustration. Then again it is the most precious of rewards to finally figure out their patterns and master the game. Once you have done that you can spend points on ingame unlockables (that is a rarity nowadays). The game is its most fun when you combo your way through normal and hard mode. My personal problem with the game is my ambition to beat it on hardest difficulty. Runs in this game take almost over an hour on this mode and the hardest sections are certainly the last two levels. "Hardest" might even be an understatement because you are clearly supposed to stock up on extends to this point. Once you have reached "Death Island" the smallest of mistakes will cost you everything you have worked for. Now you reach the final boss with one life remaining, whis he is able to shred away with is machine gun. I simply cant invest that much time in such long runs to fail on the last two screens of the game. The only solution would be a stage select to train easier, but I believe the developer is going to keep the game as is.
So in short I can reccomend this game to any beat em up fan. It's biggest problems are character balance, enemies camping off screen, cheap enemy AI and one hour long runs.

35696802.review:
제가 90년대 초중반 오락실을 집처럼 들락날락거리던 세대라 그런지 비뎀업/벨트스크롤 액션게임 장르를 특히나 좋아하는데 이 "Fight'N Rage"는 정말 오랜만에 보는, 그래서 더욱 반가운 액션 게임입니다.

레트로 스타일의 느낌이 물씬 풍기는 도트 그래픽, 간단하면서도 익숙해지기 쉬운 조작체계, 다양한 엔딩 분기, 게임에 등장하는 모든 캐릭터들(주인공 3인방과 조무래기 및 보스 캐릭터들 모두)로 진행하는 스코어 어택 모드, 연습 모드 등등... 선물상자와 다를바가 없다고 생각합니다.

살짝 아쉬운 점을 적어보자면, 우선 각 캐릭터별 히든 스킬의 커맨드가 복잡하고 어려워 실전에서 사용하기가 매우 어렵다는 것과 난이도가 상승할수록 적들의 인공지능이 짜증을 유발한다는 점, 멀티플레이가 지원되지 않는다는 점... 정도군요.

킬링타임용으로도 충분히 재미있고 다양한 콤보로 적들을 얼마나 화려하게, 많이 때려부수나 연구하는 맛도 각별한 게임입니다. 이런 류의 벨트스크롤 액션게임을 좋아하신다면 구입하셔도 절대 후회하지 않을 겁니다.

※ 추가로 각 캐릭터별 숨겨진 기술은 다음과 같습니다.
걸(GAL): 점프 킥 - 바운드 - 지상에 착지하기 전 ↑ + 공격 버튼 입력. or 백 점프(점프 버튼 누른 다음 캐릭터가 바라보는 방향의 반대쪽을 입력) - 지상에 착지하기 전 ↑ + 공격 버튼 입력.
F.노리스(F.NORRIS): ↓↘→↗ + SP. 스페셜 게이지를 소모합니다.
리카르도(RICARDO): 타우로 어퍼컷(↓↑ + 공격) 사용 후 공격 버튼을 계속 누르고 있기 - 지상에 착지하기 전 공격 버튼 떼기.

О боевке:
Тут она довольно простая на первый взгляд, классические 3 кнопки (прыжок, атака, супер атака.) в плотную происходит захват.

"Бык" например не умеет бегать, но делает рывки а так же умеет игнорить удары по себе.
"Телка" умеет отскакивать от стен и вообще быстрая.

Детям 90х любивших в свое время такие игры как Battletoads,SoR,TMNT, и ищущих чего то подобного сейчас, рекомендую.

35350461.review:
Excellent, excellent beat 'em up brawler.  I'm impressed that one guy was able to do all of this (albeit over the course of years), and the love and care that went into making it shows.

- The combat, for only three main buttons (attack, jump, special) is surprisingly deep.  Movesets aren't particularly expansive, I don't think, but finding new opportunities to extend your combos is a blast.  Walls will be your best friends in this regard.

- The graphics are crisp and beautiful spritework at their finest.  Some characters, even among the players, are better animated than others for some reason or another, but they're all distinctive.  In fact, the fact that a vast majority of the enemy roster consists of mutants (read: animal people) makes the players stand out even more and helps them pop out.  Bonus points for options to change some of the other display options.

- In-game currency for unlocking things extends playtime for more casual folk, as well as a plethora of endings.  The simple lettering of the endings is just one subcategory, as there are variations to the cutscenes and the endings depending on the characters present.

35280662.review:
A classic arcade style beat em up with frantic gameplay, awesome music, 3 player co-op and enough content to warrant multiple playthroughs. It has your classic beat em up character archetypes with Gal being the speedy character with low damage, Richardo being the slow grappler with high health and damage, and F. Norris being the all around balanced character. The game prides itself on it's 90's over the top violence as you punch mutants until they explode into a pile of bones. As you play through arcade mode, you will come across alternate paths that change what level  you go to next and the ending you get at the end of the game. 
   As for gameplay, you have the ability to create combos using your standard attack chain and special moves as you beat up furry animals, but you need to be aware of the situations you're in. Enemies will try to surround you and crowd control is very important. You also have some defensive mechanics such as aeiral recovery, ground recovery, rolling, and parries (3rd Strike yall). 

tl;dr game's great 10/10

35253634.review:
As someone whose main interests are Megaman, Castlevania and oversaturated arcade brawlers, I'm a gamer who hasn't had much to smile about in recent years. Even going back to play those old beat-'em-ups is only halfway satisfying because I realize as an adult what I didn't as a kid: that they were cynical money-grubbing cheap shot factories that drew me in with pretty graphics and catchy music to drain as many quarters as they could get out of my acid wash jean pockets.

When my husband gifted me this game, I was cautiously optimistic because of the stellar retro style graphics and the outstanding soundtrack... and my trust was rewarded in a way I never would've expected. Fight'N Rage is the rarest of all: a difficult but fair brawler that's beatable not just by one player, but on one token, provided you're good enough. And no, that doesn't mean constantly jumpkicking or using some stupid rotation exploit! The movesets of the three playable characters are so shockingly robust that it felt at times like a fighting game that had its characters imported into a brawler vis a vis Guilty Gear:Judgment. The single developer- yeah that shocked me too- made sure that each character had enough moves that there are (with a very few exceptions) really no situations they can't get the upper hand in no matter how saturated the screen is with enemies.

The graphical and narrative style of this game is peak 90s. Roided-out, angular men, ugly mutant furries, dank alleyways, and HUGE bouncing breasts everywhere with the frequency of a sexploitation film... and I don't say that as a negative! I could see the gonzo visuals and adherence to retro style storytelling- "The evil bad men captured and/or killed these scantily clad ladies, IT'S TIME FOR REVENGE"- making some roll their eyes, and fair play to you if that's too high an entry fee, but if you're willing to part with your higher cognitive functions and 20 bucks, I can promise you this is the single most satisfying, rewarding, challenging and deep brawler experience of your life. This game is really, REALLY GOOD.

So many indie developers have tried so hard to make a proper 2D side scrollin' beat'em up like Streets of Rage or Final Fight, but most of them didn't quite nail it. River City Underground is practical example of that: good core gameplay, but everything else just messed up. And that was a kickstarter project made by a group of developers. Now this guy from Uruguay gets everything DONE without all that goddamn publicity and advertising on webzines. And by DONE I mean pretty fucking excellent side scrollin' action with combos, enemy variety, great music (this Gonzalo Varela is an amazing composer!) and fantastic 2D sprites. 

Chapeau. 

Maybe kids won't like this one, but if like me you've grown up playing beat em ups on cabinets or on the old gen consoles, then you really have to get this. It's worth your money and it's fun, frantic, strategic great combat. The game has also branching paths and secret moves! C'mon, this is just awesome! By far Ricardo is my favorite, but I am trying to get used to F.Norris, even if it's a bit hard to master :) 

I really hope this guy gets all the support he deserves! 

Peace \m/ -_- \m/

As someone who has played a lot of Cadillacs & Dinosaurs, Golden Axe, Streets of Rage and Final Fight, I can vouch that Fight'N Rage is a remarkable example of beat-em-up craftsmanship. The game offers 56 possible endings based on routes and character combinations, a crapton of unlockables and a very deep fighting system. Enemies can be juggled into insane combos and if you have a friend with you, you can even kill certain bosses in one well-coordinated combo. 

Beating the game several times doesn't just net you different endings, but you get to unlock new costumes and even regular enemies as characters to play with. Oh yeah, and if you are worried about not having friends to play with to get all the endings, the game lets you unlock a CPU partner mode to help you with that!

What's even more impressive is that it was made by just two developers, one of which only did the music.

35187922.review:
There have been a few indie beat'em ups that came out lately that came so close to being good but tripped at the finish line: Mother Russia Bleeds and 99 Vidas come to mind. These two I didn't feel made the cut because of aggrivating stage design along with too many annoying enemies to fight. They both like to overwhelm the players with so many enemies that they fill the screen if you choose to play the games with 3 friends. Add to the fact that there isn't an icon showing where the players are, it's easy to lose yourself in the on-screen mob. You get a sense that the developers thought "Hey, classic beat'em ups were coin eaters so our game should be just like that in terms of difficulty". Meanwhile the really memorable ones like Final Fight 3 and Streets of Rage 2 had you on fair grounds with your enemies.The playable characters in those two games are way too samey as well. Little to nothing in terms of mechanics that separate the playable characters and just end up feeling like palette swaps.

All these problems I had with those games aren't present here. Fight'n Rage's developer seems to really understand what makes a great and fun beat'em up, something that's easily lost on others. You get 3 characters to use in the story mode and they feel very different from one another to play as. Each having their strengths and weaknesses in more aspects than something shallow like one being stronger and one being faster (ala Mother Russia Bleeds). They have unique combos and unique ways to perform combos as well as their own special attacks. 

If you choose to play the game with 2 friends, the game won't try to just fill the screen with monsters in a futile attempt to balance the difficulty. There are a few more enemies but at a moderate degree so it's not unreasonable. The game compliments multiplayer as you can help each other extend combos which is incredibly satisfying as you're all making enemies explode into piles of bones.

The stage design is pretty to look at and very rarely incorporstes an annoying gimmick to insert a "challenge". 99 Vidas and MRB liked to do this a lot and those games suffered for it. Only one small sequence comes to mind that was bothersome, which was the bit on the raft. But it doesn't last very long so it didn't sour my enjoyment of the game. 

Something I was exceedingly thankful for was that boss fights were done well. 99Vidas had terrible boss fights that forced you to fight them a specifically limiting way or you had to throw your extra lives at them because they have no hit-stun and attack frequently. MRB had gimmicky fights that also forced you to play in a limiting fashion. In Fight'n Rage you are welcome to combo the hell out the bosses and most allow you to grapple and throw them for added enjoyment.

The only criticism I and my friends have about the game is that you aren't able to use unlockable characters in story mode; they're only for use in the battle arena mode. We really wanted to go through the game as the Doberman, Muay Thai Birds, and the Bruce Lee monkeys. Hopefully an update will allow this to happen in the future. One other criticism is that there's no online play at the moment but I'm glad the developer spent the majority of his time making sure the core game was complete and well made first-and-foremost.

There are multiple endings in the game that depend on which path you take, which character you select, and which combination of characters are present during co-op. So at the price of $20, there is plenty of conent to unlock and enjoy for this great game

35160083.review:
2017/10/04　主に操作性と分岐について修正
2017/10/07　非常に重要な部分について修正

Q.どんなゲーム？
A.[strike] 女の子の乳がみんなゴムボールみたいにブルンブルン揺れるファイナルファイトだよ。最高。 [/strike] 
まるで登場する女性キャラすべての乳がゴムボールのように揺れるような書き方をしていましたが、本当にゴムボールのように揺れるキャラはGalとそれを元にしたボス一人だけだったことを深くお詫び申し上げます。他キャラも揺れなくはないですが両名に比べると抑えめです。
もちろんその他の女性キャラの揺れ方も悪くありませんしその両名の揺れ方に関しては最高です。

わりとあっさりモブや敵の女の子が死んでいくよ。つらい。
でもみんな痴女みたいな格好してる。最高。エキストラのねーちゃんに至ってはたぶん履いてない。

Q.操作性はどう？
A.概ね思い通りに動けるよ。ただちょっと直接投げが暴発しやすかったのは気になった。
特に一部ボスには投げに対するカウンターがあるので暴発するとちょっとひどい。
投げは敵に向かって移動すればどの方向でも発生するため自分から上下に接近しようとすると発生しやすい。
まあこの手のゲームで自分から上下合わせに行くのは悪手なので問題ないといえばそうだけど。

Q.難易度はどう？
A.基本はその場復活、残機0でもステージごとのチェックポイントから始められるしコンティニュー無限だから気楽だよ。
ただ一部ステージはチェックポイントそのものがなかったりボス前にやばいポイントがあったりしてめんどくせー！ってなることはあるかも。
ゲーム自体の難易度はちょっと高いかも。敵ごとの特性を把握して適切な行動をしなければ攻撃を食らいまくること間違い無し。
イージーもトレーニングも初期状態では選べずスコアに応じて手に入るメダルで買う必要があるのもつらい（大した額じゃないけど）。

Q.エロい？
A.エロい。Galの空中スペシャルアタック発動してSSを撮ろうね。　

Q.ボリュームは？
A.この手のゲームにしては尋常じゃなくある。分岐によって総ステージ数が変動し、多い時は11ステージにもなる。
後半の分岐はどうしても少なくなってしまうが序盤の分岐はかなり種類が多い。
分岐の種類も様々で、ただの分かれ道から真逆に進む、制限時間内に選択を迫られるなど豊富。
ステージ自体もバイクに乗って敵を蹴散らしたり、筏やトラックの上、エレベーターやえっちなお店など多彩。
ちなみに分岐によってエンディングが変化し、その数なんと8種類だが一部除いて会話の組み合わせが変わるくらいなのであんまり期待しないほうがいい。

書きたいことはまだまだあるけど既に長いのが更に長くなっちゃうのでこの辺で。
2Dアクション好きを自負するなら買わなきゃハドソン。

35145147.review:
Fight'N Rage is incredible. For a one man shop, this game is absolutely amazing. One of the mechanically strongest arcade style beat-em-ups out there. 

But I hate its guts for two simple reasons: It runs way too long and it's too damn draining to play. A clear demands at least an hour in a single sitting, no saves. And the game drags that out with endless enemy waves at the end that goes well beyond "YES! A TEST OF MY SKILLS!" and into "Oh great not this bull$#!@ again!"

And Fight N Rage WANTS to kill you, too. The game is balanced to make completing a run successfully hard, even with infinite continues (That restart the zone and then the stage on higher difficulties.) So it's tough, which is good... usually... except here it's an hour long run and all the game has to do is knock you in the water or sneak one BS attack through a hitbox it should not have been able to penetrate and you can lose an incredibly rare life and sink your run 30 minutes later.

I realize all of this is pronounced in damn near every other arcade beat-em-up, but the screws in FnR are tightened so tight that all of this comes to the front. So I end up hating a game that is mechanically and graphically outstanding in every way because I end up furious at the game every time I play it. SoRR has nearly the exact same pacing issues (As it should, FnR is a love letter to SoR2 in many ways.), but it gets around this with saves, with 8 difficulties, and you pretty quickly raise the funds for stage select so if your run bombs out you can just stage select to practice or cheat your way to see the end. FnR doesn't have any of this, sadly, and runs afoul of problems we were able to ignore in earlier beat-em-ups but can't here by being a more hardcore product.

35142872.review:
This game is a very pleasant surprise!  I decided to try it on a whim since I have not really played a good beat em' up since Castle Crashers and Dungeon Fighter.

This feels very good to play, hits have impact, there are zoom-in and explosion effects during big combos, and backgrounds and characters are quite colorful with smooth animation throughout.  To think this was made by only two people is really impressive.

Fighting has depth, with an excellent combo and parry system that is reminiscent of a 2D fighting game like Street Fighter (Which is referenced a few times throughout the game).  Good crowd control and use of your entire arsenal is needed, as the game is quite challenging.  I beat it on Normal but it took some effort.  There are many unlockables, branching paths, and endings, enough to keep you busy for quite a long time.

Originally, I was offput by 20 dollars for a beat em' up, but after playing it feel the cost is justified.  Highly recommended to all beat em' up fans.  Tip for the developer:  Advertise where you can and get the word out about this fantastic game!

35114045.review:
I highly recommend purchasing this game.  This game nails every aspect of a good beat-em-up game.  If you're a fan or a newcomer to the genre, this game is a must buy.

The combat mechanics are perfect, even though there are only 3 buttons to press, there is surprisingly a good amount of combos that you can pull off.  Also the combat feels very satisfying, every attack has a lot of weight behind it which in turns makes it very satisfying to punch enemies.

The stage design is fairly simple with multiple branching paths that you can take.

Music is excellent.  I'm don't really care for music in video games, but the soundtrack in this game sticks out a lot to me in a good way.  It has the "pumped up" feeling which makes you want to go berserk and destroy everything in the game.

There are many unlockables in the game, such as skins, which gives it a very high replay value.

Overall I am very satisfied with the game, this is definitely one of the best beat-em-ups I have played in a very long time.  The price is a little high, but you will definitely get your moneys worth and much more.  Definitely do put it at the top of your wishlist and wait for a sale, you really do not want to miss out on this game.

35108344.review:
[h1]Resumen[/h1]
Muy recomendable. de los mejores beat em up que he jugado en los últimos años, Fight'N Rage mezcla varias características de otros beat em up de los 90  para conseguir una esencia propia, si tengo que definir el juego en pocas palabras tendría que decir que es como el remake de street of rage pero mejorado ya incluye historia con diferentes caminos y finales, un sistema de combos muy completo y muy bien realizado. 

[b]Pro[/b]
- Multitud de opciones gráficas, puedes apagar los modos CRT, bloom, etc.
- Excelente diseño gráfico y sonoro.
- Solido sistema de combeo.
- Varios modos, incluyendo uno de lucha.
- Mucho contenido desbloqueable y múltiples caminos a seguir, lo que alarga enormemente la experiencia de juego.
- Control simple (cruceta y 3 botones) pero que permite una gran variedad de movimientos y combos que requiere tiempo y practica llegar a dominar, pero que se disfruta desde el primer momento.
- Beat um ep justo con el jugador, pero no por eso fácil.

[b]Contra[/b]
- Si tengo que buscarle una contra al juego, sería la falta de un cooperativo en línea, entiendo que al ser un juego creado por 2 personas es difícil agregar esta funcionalidad, y por un lado, soy de los que prefiere que no la tenga a tener una mal implementada, pero es que este juego pide a gritos jugarlo con amigos y hoy en día lo más fácil es hacerlo mediante un cooperativo online.
NOTA: El juego si tiene cooperativo, pero local.

[h1]Mi experiencia[/h1]
Un beat em up clásico, o sea, 2D side scroll (la pantalla se mueve horizontalmente) pero con una pantalla adaptada a los monitores actuales (16/9 en vez de 4/3), con una estética pixel art colorida.
A nivel técnico no lo he encontrado ninguna falla, el juego se ejecuta sin problemas a pantalla completa   donde te recibe el menú principal, donde puedes seleccionar los diferentes modos o cambias la opciones gráficas o de sonido.
Las opciones son las clásicas como resolución, pantalla completa, etc. Además de tener las opciones para apagar o modificar los efectos de post proceso, como el CRT, scan line, etc.

El juego consta de varios modos, el principal o modo árcade es donde deberemos ir recorriendo varios escenarios enfrentando a todo mutante que se nos ponga por delante, para ellos constamos de solo 3 botones, golpe, salto y especial. Es posible avanzar solo machacando el botón de golpe, lo que es ideal para gente sin experiencia en este genero, pero el verdadero potencial del juego consiste en ir creando combos al combinar diferentes movimientos, por ejemplo, puedes correr y entrar con un rodillazo a tu enemigo, en el acto, enlazar con una secuencia de 3 combos para luego elevar a tu enemigo en el aire con una patada digna Guille y rematarlo en el aire con un movimiento especial.
La dificultad del juego no es fácil y toma tiempo dominarlo para poder llegar al final, sin embargo en ningún momento se siente injusto, al contrario, el juego siempre te da una oportunidad de esquivar o bloquear.
El modo árcade no solo nos presenta una historia, si no, que esta dependerá de nuestras decisiones y acciones, por ejemplo si salvas a la chica del primer nivel, se te abrirá un camino nuevo y conocerás un poco más de la historia de tu personaje, etc.
Mención especial tiene el escenario donde vas atropellando mutantes con una moto, en plan Cadillacs and Dinosaurs (el beat en up de árcade).

Por si todo esto fuera poco, el juego incorpora un modo de lucha versus, donde podrás competir con la CPU o contra un amigo y donde no estarás limitado a los 3 personajes iniciales, si no, que podrás ir desbloqueando y jugar con las unidades enemigas.

En un inicio, muchas opciones del juego estarán bloqueadas y tendrás que ir jugando para poder desbloquearlas, el sistema funciona de forma similar al remake de street of rage, donde cada vez que juegas te dan unas monedas según se el puntaje que consigues, con esas monedas desbloqueas diferentes trajes para tus héroes, enemigos para el modo lucha, etc.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]
Un beat em up clásico, solido, muy bien realizado, que toma prestadas varias referencias y mecánicas a otros juegos similares y que lo logra mezclar todo de una forma genial. El juego entretiene y se siente solido, muy bien equilibrado y sobre todo, muy gratificante a la hora de jugar y reventar a tus enemigos.
Si eres un amante de los beat em up clásicos, este juego no puede faltar en tu colección, de lo mejor que he visto en este genero en varios años.

Castle Crashers wasn't for me. Mother Russia Bleeds left me cold, but this? This one might just replace Streets of Rage Remake as my favourite brawler. It's tight, responsive and fast. 35097043.review:
I bought this game within minutes of it coming available, but I wanted to wait until I got a good gist of the game before I put out a review. Hopefully this will help you make the decision if this game is for you or not.

First off, a little about me, because it's very important as to why I picked this game up after only becoming aware of it the day prior to it's release, and why I did so for the $20 price tag, which seemed to have generated a little negative buzz from people who thought $10 was a better price. I'm 31 years old. I was born the year Super Mario Bros. was released, and I grew up with classic 80s leftovers and early 90s 2D pixel hits. I remember playing Final Fight 2 and especially Final Fight 3 on my SNES, and playing Streets of Rage 2 on the Genesis that belonged to the kid across the street. 

Two days prior to my writing this review, I was randomly searching upcoming titles, just to see if there were any gems that weren't given much hype. This game popped up. I looked at the graphics, I looked at the gameplay and I watched a little video on it, and immediately placed it on my wishlist. Why? Because this game looked like it was an homage, or the torch bearer of these old pixelated beat em up classics. So when the game dropped for $20, I bought it - without hesitation - as soon as Steam sent me the alert. And you know what? I was exactly right about this game. 

From the introduction, I knew this would be a love letter to games I played in my youth. The game opens with the filter set to imitate a tube television already on (scanlines included), and you're treated to some "technical text" overlaying a black background. Anyone who waited for the local arcade to turn on the machines in the morning will recognize this instantly as the old arcade startup screen, specifically the one used in Capcom games. 

From that point on, you are treated to a game that has so many homage or inside joke references to older beat em up and fighting games of this era that you can't help but feel the nostalgia dripping off the screen - provided, of course, that you ARE nostalgic for that period of gaming. There are honestly so many "old school references" that I can't remember them all to put down. Firstly, the name of the game - "Fight'N Rage." While not confirmed, it wouldn't surprise me if the developer deliberately crunched the titles Streets of Rage and Final Fight together to come up with this one. The primary character, Gal, has a name that is deliberately a nod toward Guy from Final Fight. Gal's walk animation is nearly identical to the stiff walk that both Guy and SOR's Axel have. Your first boss is an enemy dressed like M. Bison from Street Fighter, who also happens to have the iconic slide move Bison has retained all these years, and his animation frame while doing it identically copies Bison's frame from Street Fighter II. The list goes on and on, and it's best not to spoil everything here. It's strongly recommended you save any other old school references for your playthrough of the game.

So while this game IS in many ways a torch bearer for the old beat em ups, it does have it's own improvements over these older games. Obviously, controls are far superior, as are the animations of the characters. As with the old beat em ups, your character has a special move (multiple ones, actually), and like the older games of this genre, performing it will decrease some of your health. These moves have always been crowd clearers and escape effort attacks, and beings as they are stronger than standard attacks, the loss of health is justified, lest everyone just mash the attack through the whole game without penalty (Axel's "Bare Knuckle" in SOR2 is a good example of this). However, Fight'N Rage offers a decent balance - your character has an additional meter that fills up automatically over time. Once this meter is filled, your special attack is consequence-free. You will not lose health by performing it. Important to note, this meter is NOT a slow meter. It doesn't fill up exceptionally fast, nor is it a slow turtle. It's got a really good balance that means you'll see specials often in a level, but not so much that enemies can't touch you. This whole setup is great, as performing these specials not only help in garnering some breathing room or taking down enemies, but also in "destroying" an enemy, netting you additional points as their body explodes into bones. Points are crucial, as you gain a life for every X amount of points.

That is not uncommon in beat em ups, but the points are more crucial with this game, as it does tend to be on the harder side, and lives do not come easily. The difficulty is something that has garnered criticism for this game. Yes, it is difficult, but when you consider just how closely this is linked to the old beat em ups of yesteryear, it shouldn't be much of a surprise. This game is built like an arcade game set to free play. It's not the easiest walk in the park, and the game doesn't hold your hand for long. Still, I don't think it's the hardest thing out there. In truthfulness, I have yet to beat the game, but I have reached the final boss, and simply lost because of a numbers game with near zero life. Thing is, I KNOW where my dilemma is - it lies with a certain fight right before the final room - and so I know that I have to learn how to counter this enemy in order to save health for the finale. I don't in any way feel stuck, and know it won't be long before I DO beat the final boss. (To give you an idea, my first playthrough only lasted through the first stage of the second level, and in my death, I barely racked up enough points to hit 70 coins [more on coins in a moment]. 3 playthroughs later and I can get to the final stage on the same "quarter" I started with)

Despite the difficulty, this game is incredibly accessible. It has enough to it to learn the game and get the gist of it quickly without feeling overwhelmed. I will give an example: as much as I love River City Ransom, and the modernized sequel available on Steam, these games can be far less accessible. RCR has a number of RPG elements to it, and don't me wrong - that's fine; I love River City Ransom - but this means to start out, these games require more effort into getting acustom to everything. River City Ransom: Underground is even moreso like this. Again, that's not to say the game isn't good - it IS a lot of fun, from what I've played of it - but this is the reason why, despite have RCR:U for months now, I've already invested more time in Fight'N Rage. It's ease of gameplay is reminiscent to Streets of Rage, Final Fight, Double Dragon, etc., and it makes this game a classic "pick up and play." For someone like myself, sporting a 9 to 5 office job and a family to boot, I don't have as much time to play games, so I'm going to gravitate toward something I can get right into.

The game features in-game currency, which you receive by automatically trading in your points every time you die or beat the game. There is a lot to unlock here, including enemies that can be used in a versus battle mode, and alternate costumes [primarily color designs] for the three main characters. I think this certainly increases the replayability of the title.

There are 7 or 8 stages to this game, depending on the various paths you take (multiple paths, another plus), and I would say the length of a playthrough is about the same, maybe a little longer than the old school beat em ups. In other words, this is a game beatable in one sitting that won't make you feel like your entire day is gone afterward, which is important considering there's no sort of "save now, play later" feature.

Final note, Gal and practically all the women in this game are nice eye candy, even if they are sprites, meaning this game gives you cheesecake to factor in as well, if that rocks your boat. 

Overall, if you like 90s nostalgia and a game that sits on the more challenging side, PICK THIS UP. NOW.

35096173.review:
Fight'N Rage is a rare example of a retro-styled game that knows what made the games of the time it's emulating so memorable, while also innovating and adapting to the games that have come since. As soon as you boot it, you're taken to a different time in gaming history -- in the good way -- and put into the mood to put your boot to the opposition.

Good thing, then, that the gameplay that follows is satisfying, challenging, and delightfully brutal, and while the characters' movesets are a bit simple, if still more robust than most such games, the ability to string damn near any attack into another onto a reeling enemy provides an additional layer of skill, incentivizing you to use your toolset to produce spectacular results. Even with the assortment of palette-swapped enemies typical of this genre coming at you in waves, you're constantly trying to maintain impressive juggles with your hapless opponents and keep your combo count up, offsetting potential monotony and giving way instead to white-knuckle, palm-sweating excitement. Timing windows to combo your attacks feel good, and there are several opportunities to cancel and reset your combos mid-way, a la fighting games -- try dashing or jumping in the middle of a combo once you've stunned or lifted your enemy off the ground, and chasing after flying or wall-bounced enemies! -- allowing you to pile on major damage. The touchy commands themselves can cause some occasional accidental chaos, but it generally doesn't cost you too badly, and sometimes even amusingly works in your favor.

The visuals are also up to speed, with expressive, animated characters and lively backgrounds perfectly framing your path of destruction, itself punctuated with great feedback as you lay waste to the opposition. The style well imitates the times it draws from, but also has lots of polish to bring the game to life in a way that wasn't possible back then. The music is solid and appropriate, if not particularly memorable, and the sound effects are great, with your most vicious hits providing an equally glorious earful. The female characters are a little over-the-top with the thrashing breasts, and thongs apparently being the only lower-body wear in the universe, but it's in good fun, so whatever. There are also several cases of sprites that are outright lifted and adapted from other games, but you won't care about the cut corners too much once the action gets properly underway -- assuming you even noticed them in the first place.

Another thing the game remembered from the days of yore was the difficulty, and the game definitely provides a meaty challenge that requires you to adapt to your opponents and find openings to safely deliver punishment; even as a veteran of the genre, and a quick study of game mechanics, I met an inglorious end and my first Continue screen midway through the fifth stage of Normal difficulty. But for the more ham-fisted or simply less experienced among us that may struggle sooner and find themselves frustrated, consider taking a breath and adapting to the game before asking that it adapt to you; any enemies in the air or currently hit-stunned is an opportunity to continue your combo, and you can maintain or finish them with your SP gauge, not to mention use it to get yourself out of trouble, so remember to use the tools available to you; they're no good to you if you don't utilize them. Also remember to hit the Extras menu and buy the training mode to get an idea of what you can do with the game's engine; it'll give you some bread and butter combos, as well as some ideas to come up with your own, although I would argue it should've just been available in the first place.

Speaking of the extras menu, it also contains a suite of other unlockable content and small customization elements, bringing to mind the shop of the fan-made Streets of Rage Remake, and like that shop, more play means more currency to find out what else the game has tucked away, which is additional incentive to dole out some more knuckle sandwiches.

On the whole, Fight'N Rage is an example of a game that knows what was great about an era of video games, but also knows what needed refinement, and it delivers both to great effect, largely succeeding in its bold mission statements. There are a couple of snags -- flying enemies are as annoying as you remembered them in Streets of Rage, for instance -- but overall the presentation is great, the action is thrilling, and the challenge is fair... mostly. This is a modern classic that doesn't just hang with the best of a bygone era -- it surpasses many of them. If you have any fondness of this genre, or even just its era, and aren't afraid to do more than relentlessly pound your character's basic combo, strap on your gloves and hit the streets!
